prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5291N
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the distribution and kinematics of CO(1-0)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz, corresponding to 2.6 km/s at 113 Ghz. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the CO line, having an expected width of 15 km/s, and investigate the internal kinematics of the galaxy, having an expected rotation velocity of 40 km/s. During the data analysis, we may also use Hanning smoothing to boost the signal-to-noise ratio and study CO at lower densities. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, this will allow us to reach an rms of 0.01 mJy that might be enough to detect continuum emission if very cold dust is present.

Based on HI data from the VLA, we expect the CO-emitting gas to cover regions smaller than 8"x5" in each channel map. This is well below the largest angular size filtered out by the proposed configuration. We also estimate that the CO disc has a diameter of ~16". A spatial resolution of 1.5" will provide about 10 beams along the major axis and allow us to trace a well-sampled rotation curve. For an assumed distance of 58 Mpc, 1.5" corresponds to about 400 pc. This spatial resolution is comparable with that of available Halpha images and IFU datacubes from VLT-MUSE, thus we could compare CO maps with SFR maps at sub-kpc scales.

NGC 5291N was detected in CO(1-0) with the SEST (see Fig.1) giving an integrated CO flux of 5 Jy km/s. The CO line-width is 130 km/s and fully consistent with the HI line-width, indicating that HI and CO gas share a similar kinematical behaviour. B-array VLA observations indicate that the HI gas forms a rotating disc, thus we expect that the large CO line-width is also due to rotation. The SEST beam is considerably larger than the rotating HI disc and associated star-forming regions. Considering that molecular gas is typically associated with high-column-density HI gas (above 10^21 cm^-2), we expect the CO emitting region to cover a total area of 16"x10", corresponding to 71 synthesized beams for the requested spatial resolution of 1.5". Assuming a typical velocity dispersion of 6 km/s for the CO gas, we expect CO line profiles with a width of 15 km/s and average flux density of 5 [Jy km/s] /71 /15 [km/s] = 5 mJy/beam which would be presumably peaked at the line center. In order to trace the CO kinematics, we request a channel width of 2.6 km/s and a noise level of 1 mJy per channel, yielding a peak signal-to-noise ratio of 7 for an average spatial position. Possible CO emission with lower flux densities will be studied by smoothing the data in both space and velocity, further increasing the signal-to-noise ratio per channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC5291S
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the distribution and kinematics of CO(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz, corresponding to 2.6 km/s at 113 Ghz. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the CO line, having an expected width of 15 km/s, and investigate the internal kinematics of the galaxy, having an expected rotation velocity of 25 km/s. During the data analysis, we may also use Hanning smoothing to boost the signal-to-noise ratio and study CO gas at lower densities. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, this will allow us to reach an rms of 0.01 mJy that might be enough to detect continuum emission if very cold dust is present.

Based on HI data from the VLA, we expect the CO-emitting gas to cover regions smaller than 12"x5" in each channel map. This is well below the largest angular size filtered out by the proposed configuration. We also estimate that the CO disc has a diameter of ~24". A spatial resolution of 1.5" will provide about 16 beams along the major axis and allow us to trace a well-sampled rotation curve. For an assumed distance of 58 Mpc, 1.5" corresponds to about 400 pc. This spatial resolution is comparable with that of available Halpha images, thus we could compare CO maps with SFR maps at sub-kpc scales.

NGC 5291S was detected in CO(1-0) with the SEST (see Fig.1) giving an integrated CO flux of 8 Jy km/s. The CO line-width is 70 km/s and fully consistent with the HI line-width, indicating that HI and CO gas share a similar kinematical behaviour. B-array VLA observations indicate that the HI gas forms a rotating disc, thus we expect that the large CO line-width is also due to rotation. The SEST beam is considerably larger than the rotating HI disc and associated star-forming regions. Considering that molecular gas is typically associated with high-column-density HI gas (above 10^21 cm^-2), we expect the CO emitting region to cover a total area of 24"x10", corresponding to 107 synthesized beams for the requested spatial resolution of 1.5". Assuming a typical velocity dispersion of 6 km/s for the CO gas, we expect CO line profiles with a width of 15 km/s and average flux density of 8 [Jy km/s] /107 /15 [km/s] = 5 mJy/beam which would be presumably peaked at the line center. In order to trace the CO kinematics, we request a channel width of 2.6 km/s and a noise level of 1 mJy per channel, yielding a peak signal-to-noise ratio of 7 for an average spatial position. Possible CO emission with lower flux densities will be studied by smoothing the data in both space and velocity, further increasing the signal-to-noise ratio per channel.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7252NW
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the distribution and kinematics of CO(1-0)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz, corresponding to 2.6 km/s at 113 Ghz. This is sufficient to resolve the shape of the CO line, having an expected width of 15 km/s, and investigate the internal kinematics of the galaxy, having an expected rotation velocity of 20 km/s. During the data analysis, we may also use Hanning smoothing to boost the signal-to-noise ratio and study CO gas at lower densities. The remainder of the spectral windows are set to achieve a maximum bandwidth in order to observe the millimeter continuum. With the observing time needed for the primary line observations, this will allow us to reach an rms of 0.01 mJy that might be enough to detect continuum emission if very cold dust is present.

Based on HI data from the VLA, we expect the CO-emitting gas to cover regions smaller than 6"x3" in each channel map. This is well below the largest angular size filtered out by the proposed configuration. We also estimate that the CO disc has a diameter of ~12". A spatial resolution of 1.5" will provide about 8 beams along the major axis and allow us to trace a rotation curve. For an assumed distance of 66.5 Mpc, 1.5" corresponds to about 460 pc. This spatial resolution is comparable with that of available Halpha images, thus we could compare CO maps with SFR maps at sub-kpc scales.

NGC 7252NW has a clear single-dish detection in CO(2-1) and a tentative detection in CO(1-0) (see Fig.1). This gives an integrated CO flux of 1.3 Jy km/s. The CO line-width is uncertain but consistent with the HI line-width, indicating that HI and CO gas share a similar kinematical behaviour. B-array VLA observations indicate that the HI gas forms a rotating disc, thus we expect that the large CO line-width is also due to rotation. The single-dish beam is considerably larger than the rotating HI disc and associated star-forming regions. Considering that molecular gas is typically associated with high-column-density HI gas (above 10^21 cm^-2), we expect the CO emitting region to cover a total area of 12"x6", corresponding to 32 synthesized beams for the requested spatial resolution of 1.5". Assuming a typical velocity dispersion of 6 km/s for the CO gas, we expect CO line profiles with a width of 15 km/s and average flux density of 1.3 [Jy km/s] /32 /15 [km/s] = 3 mJy/beam which would be presumably peaked at the line center. In order to trace the CO kinematics, we request a channel width of 2.6 km/s and a noise level of 0.75 mJy per channel, yielding a peak signal-to-noise ratio of 5-6 for an average spatial position. Possible CO emission with lower flux densities will be studied by smoothing the data in both space and velocity, further increasing the signal-to-noise ratio per channel.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Gravitational interactions between galaxies can extrude debris like tidal tails. Tidal Dwarf Galaxies (TDGs) can form in these debris. The tidal interactions effectively segregate dynamically-cold baryons from dynamically-hot dark matter (DM), hence we expect TDGs to be largely devoid of DM contrary to typical dwarfs. TDGs also have higher metallicities than typical dwarfs, having originated from more massive galaxies. TDGs thus serve as important testbeds of galaxy dynamics and star formation (SF).
We propose CO(1-0) observations of three TDGs with single-dish CO detections. VLA observations show that TDGs have rotating HI discs and are consistent with our expectations on their dynamics, but the limited spatial resolution also admits other interpretations. ALMA is the only facility that can resolve these gas discs both spatially and in velocity. We aim to derive high-quality velocity fields and rotation curves to build mass models of TDGs and investigate any DM content (baryonic or non-baryonic) they may retain from the discs of their progenitors. We will also combine CO maps with multiwavelength observations to study the spatially-resolved SF law in these unusual dwarf galaxies.
